segments.text: One, two, three, four, one, two, three, four, testing.
One, two, three, four, one, two, three, four, testing.
This is bringing philosophers to life in the background somewhere.
Get that on him.
This is Monday, April the 2nd, and we're in the Heritage Preservation Outer Office in the library, and I have the honor and pleasure of interviewing Dr. Jack Campbell about his work
three decades of service here at Texas A&M.

To begin with, Jack, to introduce yourself to anyone who listens or who reads, give a biographical summary of yourself growing up, where, when, what did mom and dad do, high school, college, experience before you came to A&M.
Well, the year of my birth was 1927 when Lindbergh flew across the Atlantic.
I was born in Chicago, Illinois.
My father was working for Armour and Company as one of the earliest personnel or industrial engineers.
He was originally from Duluth, Minnesota.
My mother was from Indiana, and my parents met at the University of Indiana in the 1920s.
We lived in an apartment in Chicago.
until I was about seven.
Went to school in the city when the Depression was starting, and it was pretty rough.
And my experience in school was great if I didn't get knocked down at least one or two times.
About the time I was seven, we moved out to Downers Grove, which was 20 miles west of Chicago.
and my father would take the train into work and I had the advantages of going to suburban schools.
I graduated from high school
Which high school?
Downers Grove High School.
They just had one high school.
I was president of the senior class, somewhat active in school.
But it was the last year the Cubs won the pennant, I remember, in 1945.
It sticks in my mind.
From there, I was
4F for the Army.
The war was about over and I failed.
I had heart murmur and bad ears.
And so I went to college at Cornell in Mount Vernon, Iowa and majored in history.
When I graduated in 1949, I wasn't sure what I was going to do, but I always wanted to be a writer.
And I thought the great American novel would be in the Chicago Stockyards, the slaughterhouse of the world.
So I got a job as an industrial engineer at Armors, but didn't care for it too much and decided I'd go into teaching after a year of industrial engineering.
And I applied to the University of Illinois to get teacher certification.
And I got a job in the summer of 1950 as a camp counselor in New Hampshire.
25th of June of that year, the Korean War started.
I was one of the first to be called in, and this time I passed the physical.
But I was already at the University of Illinois and was deferred until the end of the school year.

at which time I entered the Navy on July the 9th, 1951, for a four-year enlistment, serving at the Atlantic Fleet headquarters in Norfolk, aboard a heavy cruiser, the Macon, and then the last year with a squadron at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.
On discharge, I...
I went back to the University of Illinois for a year to finish a master's and a teaching certificate, and got married.
How much of this?
Is this all right?
I don't want to use too much tape, because I've got a lot of marriages.
Anyway, my wife was a singer, and she'd been on Broadway in The King and I as the chorus, and she wanted to come back to New York, so I got a job after
I was certified at Manhasset on Long Island while she tried to get a job on Broadway again.
After about two years of teaching there, I was discouraged and wanted to work on a doctorate.
I had been taking a few courses at Columbia.
About the time my marriage was breaking up, I decided to go full time at Columbia Teachers College, where I worked with my master's leader was Dr. Lawrence Kremen.
After about two years, I got a teaching job at Cranford, New Jersey.

became the chairman of the history department at the high school, taught there about five years, completed the doctorate with a dissertation on Colonel Francis W. Parker, a father of progressive education.
The next thing I did was to get a job as teaching at Brooklyn College.
where I taught some foundation history and philosophy courses, but mostly supervised social studies teachers in the various schools of Brooklyn.
It was a very fine experience, teaching-wise.
But the commute from New Jersey was two hours each way.
And I started looking for another position and was chosen as the head of the Department of Education at Lycoming College in Williamsport, Pennsylvania.
And there, in a small liberal arts college, I developed the programs and taught supervised student teachers, but was not able to fully develop my interest in the history and philosophy of education.
In 1970, I met Glenn Johnson.
who was head of the education department at Texas A&M when I was at a meeting in Chicago.
And we liked each other, and he invited me to come down to look at Texas A&M.
Before I got there, I believe President Rutter, who I had heard so much about, had died.
I was offered a position and came to Texas A&M in the fall of 1970.
As far as you know, was there a search committee?
Oh, yes.
They were developing the College of Education, which had been established one year earlier.
It had been a department.
and they were looking for foundation people.
Glenn Johnson was also a graduate of Teachers College Columbia.
The man I was named after was Carnegie.
They called him Andy.
And he had taught economics at Texas A&M.
Before that had been a vice president for some insurance company.
And he had recommended Texas A&M to me, Andy Carnegie.
When you and Glenn met at a professional meeting, as far as you knew, what was this position?
What was it described as being?
The position was described as in foundations of education, which was exactly what I had been prepared to do, but had been doing everything at Lycoming College.
So it was ideal for me, and I thought it would be a wonderful place for the children.
Now, as far as you knew, what did you know about Texas A&M at that point?

Only that it was a wonderful place from Andy Carnegie, who was not exactly my godfather, but he had been my father's boss at Armoring Company, and my father thought he'd make points by naming me after him, but he left Armors.
Spell his last name.
K-E-N-A-G-Y.
He was quite active in the community as well as in economics and was one of the founders of the, I think it's the retirement nursing home, Briarcrest.
And he was on the Governor's Commission for Aging.
So what you knew about A&M at that time was positive.
Positive.
As far as you knew, what was A&M like before you came to?
Well, I was very ignorant of Texas and wasn't just sure of the geography.
I didn't know up from down or Dallas from Houston.
I had to look at a map.
had never really considered Texas.
But I had the wonderful glowing accounts from Andy Carnegie.
So I came here, and from the very first moment I fell in love with it.
The trees were in bloom.
It was spring, I guess.
The students were so friendly.
Up north at Lycoming, the teacher was the enemy of the people.
Down here, the students seemed to be so friendly and so nice.
I remember I stepped on the grass looking at a tree, and a student very politely told me it was sacred ground.
It impressed me very much.
Just fell in love with the university from the very first moment.
As far as you know, were you the only person interviewed for this job?
At the time I came down for the interview, I was the only one.
There were others.
I remember Jim Rollins was one of them.
hired at the same time, but I was the only one, and I went through the various stages of ultimately getting to meet Dean Hubert, who was, of course, very impressive.
Describe your first impression of Frank Hubert.
Well, he impressed me as being extremely insightful and
As I got to know him better later, I realized he was not only insightful, but he was very powerful.
He was kind of like a Toscanini.
He made you play better than you knew how to.
I had great respect for him.
There was also another man, and I can't remember his name, who I was working with.
Dean Hubert, and developing an off-campus program that was quite extensive.
Did Hubert ask you some key questions?
Well, I'm sure he did, but I've lost the key to that.
It wasn't just you got acquainted session?
Oh, no, no.
He asked me questions about my
education, about my position.
I don't believe he asked me anything about my slant, my philosophy of education, although we talked, I'm sure, about philosophy.
Who were the other key people you met with on that list?
Well, the one person I can't think of is
I left shortly after I got here.
But, of course, Glenn Johnson was one of thewell, sponsored me, actually.
I remember talking with Bob Schuetz, who became a very good friend of mine later.
At that time, he was in the curriculum development at our department.
I'm sorry, I can't think of the name of this.
As you understood it, you were going to be responsible for what courses and what specialties?
I was going to work with the introductory courses, which were called foundations.
There was the history of American education, and then there was the history of
a world education.
There were the two basic courses that they had.
These were undergraduate.
We did not have the graduate program, but I was told that they would have you work on a graduate program as I
moved along.
I was also interested in the comparative education.
There was a Pan-American dimension that was going on at this time, connecting the university with Mexico.
Comparative education was also one of my fields at Columbia.
And so they made the offer, and this is the only dollar question we're going to ask.
What was your beginning salary?
I can remember it very well.
It was $17,000, and I think at the time I was making around $10,000 as chairman of the Department of Education at Lycoming, maybe $11,000.
So this was, I couldn't believe the salary.
And I'm assuming that the living costs here
were not higher.
No, no, it was much, much better.
And housing was much better.
As a matter of fact, the day I was interviewed, I was also shown around by a real estate agent to get an idea of the housing.
And there weren't any apartments at the time, very few, it seemed as though, but houses were readily available.
And so you moved down here then in the fall or summer?
In summer.
Moved in the summer and got, I think it was in July, and then I spent the rest of the summer in the library developing bibliographies and getting acquainted on campus.
My first class was in the fall.
And as you began to get acquainted on campus,
What was your feeling about the way newcomers were received?
It was just marvelous.
In fact, there was several days of going around being told about the insurance plan being introduced to many aspects of the community, and even a dinner over in the core building
which introduced me to the Corps, and it was very impressive.
And I remember, I think I spilled a little bit of coffee or something on one of the cadets, and I wanted to pay for the cleaning, and he refused to do that.
But the cadets were just so nice.
But that was one of the features of dinner with the Corps of Cadets.
All right, Dr. Williams wasn't yet here,
General Ludeke was the interim.
Did he, by chance, welcome people?
Yes, we had a, I don't remember now if it was just the new people or all of the faculty, but I remember meeting him and shaking his hand at a reception.
And this was the department of what?
I was in the Department of Educational Curriculum and Instruction.
Describe that department and who the key people were then.
Our offices were in the old academic building.
My office was on the fourth floor, and I had the big room.
I had big classes, you know, 80 or 90.
Glenn Johnson was the department head.
And Bob Schuetz was in English, Jim Rollins was new and he was in math ed.
Joe Illica was in reading.
Del Yank was in science education.
But we were like a little happy family and we were all excited about developing our program.
How many were in the department total?
Well, there were a few who were part-time, who supervised students.
I don't think, I know there weren't more than 10.
About how many majors were there then, do you remember?
Well, there were, we were, my memory doesn't, I remember there were only 14,000 students on campus.
And women were new, and most of them, I think, were in our department.
But I can't remember how many majors we had, but it was becoming a big department in terms of majors.
And the dean office down on the second floor, I believe, didn't he?
I think the dean was in the library, maybe.
Was that possible?
When we were in the academic building, he must have been.
there in that building, but I can't picture that now.
I remember the big Liberty Bell was down on the ground floor at the time.
What were your first impressions of A&M students in terms of their capability and their interests and so forth?
Well, of course, I was very impressed with how good they were and receptive to learning.
I think in the beginning, my students were not that good in spelling and grammar, as I might have expected, but that soon changed.
But they were very eager, very conscientious,
and very respectful.
I remember being called sir, which I wasn't sure if that was a compliment or not at first.
As a matter of fact, a little incidentally, I had a lot of corps students and I wondered just why so many in the corps wanted to go into education.
I was teaching the introductory course
And I found out that most of them just wanted to see what girls were like.
So that's why they were coming into these courses.
And the first year or two, about what was the male-female ratio in your classes?
I had more women, I think, than men, even in the beginning.
I had rather large classes, not exceptionally large, but I would have fifty or more in some of those introductory courses.
My impression was, other than coreI also had Reveille in one of my first classes, and I thought the dog was so smart, he knew when the bell was supposed to ring.
and he would start growling, and I didn't know until later that he was taught to do that, make sure we didn't go overtime.
But the students are just marvelous.
Did they tell you in advance who Reveley was and that was okay?
Yes, oh yes, they explained to me this.
He was the keeper of the flame, so to speak, and the dog just sat there very quietly, but about the time
And at first I thought, well, people are shuffling their feet.
He didn't like the shuffling.
He thought there was a little anxiety there and the class needed to bark.
But that alerted us to the time.
We didn't have bells.
Actually, I guess this is on your
report somewhere we had a bell that blew at 8 in the morning, and one at 12, and one at 5, and sort of like a mill town.
But we did not have bells in academic building, to my knowledge.
So we were on our own as far as getting students out on time.
Reveille helped us.
This is an editorial note.
Dr. Jack Kenny Williams came as president November the 1st, 1970.
One of the agreements he was able to obtain from the board of directors, they were then called, the title was not yet regents, was that they would allow him
to select one of the existing dormitories on campus and designate that dormitory for the first semester in spring of 1971 to be a woman's dorm and open to all undergraduate women.
That decision led to a sharp increase in the enrollment of women here, and in correlation with that, the number of men went up also.
And the mention of Reveille should be known by everyone that Reveille was the only non-human animal allowed into every class, every room, everywhere.
So that here was the combination.
Did the
anyone give you any orientation into Aggie vocabulary, traditions, habits?
How did you learn about this institution's traditions?
Well, of course I was interested in the history because it was my field and I
I think I pursued as much as I could the background.
I don't recall any formal introduction.
Jim Rollins, who came at the same time as I did in math ed, had been a student here, graduating in 1952.
He helped me a great deal with the traditions.
I was very much interested in them.
had hoped that I might write a biography of Earl Rudder.
I knew the history of A&M was being written at that time.
I made some overtures, but someone else was going to be doing it.
So I missed out on that, but no one ever did it.
I think his biography is not developed.
No, not done yet.
To whom did you turn for advice in those early semesters?
I think Glenn Johnson was just a marvelous leader and congenial person.
He'd had me over to his house for dinner, my wife and I.
He was, I would say, my main mentor.
Bob Schutz and I became very close.
His birthday was one day after mine.
I'm a day older than he is.
We became quite close.
As I say, we were such a small group, we often went to lunch together and worked on ideas over the lunch every day.
Where did you and friends like that, where did you all have coffee and then where did you have lunch?
It was in the MSC.
I've forgotten just where it was now.
It was not the big, it was just a little side area.
And then they developed a line later.
I think we called it the snack bar.
Snack bar.
And then the food developed more sophistication as we went along.
But we'd get a table and chat and talk.
Sometimes we brought a bag lunch.
And where did you park?
I had various parking places and for the first five years
I think 1970 to around 1975 or 76, I rode my bicycle.
It was only about two and a half miles, and in the morning it was cool enough, so I didn't work up a lot of sweat.
There was no locking of bicycles, just left them there.
And there weren't many bikes then, were there?
No.
Later I had various parking lots.
One of the last ones I remember was where that building is now.
that has all the air conditioning and equipment.
I forgot just what the name of that building is, but that was one of the best parking lots.
But for the first five years I think I rode my bicycle.
What were your assumed guidelines, your personal guidelines for the
hours you were on campus and your dress and so forth.
The policy was to be in your office at all times, which I rather liked because it gave me a chance to get prepared and do my research.
If I went home, I'd play with the children all the time, so when I would go home in the
I don't believe the first few years I had night classes.
Later on, most of my classes were at night.
But I liked that full time.
And so students were free to come in at any time.
I was in the office all the time.
And so you got here about eight and stayed until about?
Oh, at least five.
Yes, I could remember a time or two on my bicycle hearing the bell, you know, the whistle that blew all over town and realized I was going to be late to my office.
I was not late to class, but I, you could, you always knew what time it was.
This is another editorial note and typist tacked this back up
on to the first editorial note about Dr. Williams.

And I think maybe his second year here, some small group of faculty went to him to complain about the whistle that blew at 8 o'clock, 12 o'clock, 1 o'clock, and 5 o'clock that it made them feel like they were factory workers.
And so he immediately had it terminated.
Many others were disappointed that that was terminated because that, for years and years, had been a signal for the College Station neighborhood near the campus
Parents told their children, when you hear the 5 o'clock whistle, that's time for you to come back home.
And the 12 o'clock, 1 o'clock was used by the A&M consolidated school system always, so there were two sides to the argument.
Yeah.
But President Williams blew the whistle on it, is that right?
Yeah, that's right, yeah.
He blew the whistle on the whistle.
What was the, in terms of the general appearance of the faculty in those days?
What did a... Oh, we all was required to wear a coat and tie.
And of course that was my working uniform anyway.
And I don't, if I can add to it, I think it was in the energy crisis that we had the right to bear arms, so to speak.
But yes, we were very formal, but coat and tie was the regular uniform of the day.
And what about beards and long hair?
I don't think, I never tried to pass that one, but I don't believe I saw anyone.
Did anyone say anything about the coat and tie?
No, I don't believe they ever did.
It was just what you did.
I mean, I had done that as a professor at Brooklyn College and Lycoming College also.
It was expected.
And was it common for you and your colleagues to check the roll?
in those days to keep attendance?
Oh, yes.
Attendance was very vital.
I kept attendance throughout my career at A&M.
Same here, same here.
We were still in that era posting grades on our door.
in the history department.
Did you all do that?
Well, I remember it later, but I don't remember the first few years.
I remember that later we posted grades, then they put Social Security numbers down, and I think finally that
disappeared, but I don't think they did it the first few years in education.
Do you remember any anecdotes or stories about Aggie Texans giving you new excuses for missing the class or anything like that?
Do you remember some anecdotes about that?
Well, you know, there's wonderful anecdotes.
I may get them mixed up with
Well, there was always this death in the family.
I think one of them was that he couldn't get to class because a couple of his cows got out of the yard.
